qas.question: Who had increased access to better military technology?
Which institutions also hired private guards for protection?
Which class became a new military elite?
What did Shoen lack access to?
What deprived the Shoen of manpower?
What was nolonger part of the Shoen life after the ninth century?
What institutions were forbidden to form private guards?
Whom comprised most of the ordinary military?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>Shōen<b4_0/> holders<a0_0/> had access to manpower and, as they obtained <b5_0>improved military technology<b5_0/> (such as new training methods, more powerful bows, armor, horses, and superior swords) and faced worsening local conditions in the ninth century, <b6_0>military service<b6_0/> became part of shōen life. Not only the shōen but also <a1_0><b7_0>civil and religious<a1_0/> institutions<b7_0/> formed private guard units to protect themselves. Gradually, <b8_0>the <a2_0>provincial upper class<b8_0/><a2_0/> was transformed into a new military elite based on the ideals of the bushi (<a3_0>warrior<a3_0/>) or samurai (literally, one who serves).
